Issues.Body:
exportAs in @Directive metadata supports multiple values, separated by
commas. Previously it was treated as a single value string.

This commit modifies the compiler to understand that exportAs is a
string[]. It stops short of carrying the multiple values through to the
runtime. Instead, it only emits the first one. A future commit will modify
the runtime to accept all the values.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ngtsc fails building flat module out on windows
Issues.Body:
`ngtsc` currently fails building a flat module out file on Windows because it generates an invalid flat module TypeScript source file. e.g:

```ts
5 export * from './C:\Users\Paul\Desktop\test\src\export';
                ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
```

This is because `path.posix.relative` does not properly with non-posix paths, and only expects posix paths in order to work.

Issues.Title: refactor(ivy): simplify signature of appendChild / removeChild
Issues.Body:
Previously the appendChild / removeChild could take null as an argument for
a child to be added / removed. This is difficult to understand since the
mentioned methods are noop if a child is null.

This commit clarifies the appendChild / removeChild signature to systematically
require a child node to be added removed. It turns out that null could be passed
only for a very specific i18n cases so now we guard a call to removeChild with
an explicit check on the i18n side.

Issues.Title: test(ivy): enable last test in view injector integration spec
Issues.Body:
This test is failing in Ivy because of the implementation details of `ViewRef`. More precisely, because its context is lazily created (and it has to), which requires storing the `_componentIndex` in the instance when the context is not available at creation.

As a consequence, doing a deep compare of 2 `ChangeDetectorRef` created for the same view may fail in Ivy, but not in the View Engine.

# üöÄ feature request
As support for correct decimal separator by browsers is horrific (here is a good overview: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/15303940/how-to-handle-floats-and-decimal-separators-with-html5-input-type-number), basically usage of javascript is necessary to handle decimal separators correctly in an i18n app. It would be awesome if Angular (already doing a lot of i18n stuff) would have ootb support for this.



### Relevant Package
@angular/forms

### Description
Both Angular and Angular Material for now rely completely on browser behavior, which as stated, is pretty confusing. Also the easy workaround using a pattern does not work, as it does not align with specs to use it with number inputs (https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/27758#issuecomment-449198662 and https://github.com/angular/material2/issues/14575).


### Describe the solution you'd like
As Angular already uses a locale, also automagically use the correct decimal separator for this locale.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
As said, the easy workaround using a pattern does not work, as it does not align with specs to use it with number inputs (https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/27758#issuecomment-449198662).

Thank you!

ng new foo --experimentalIvy

### Versions
<!--
Output from: `node --version`, `npm --version` and `ng --version`.
  Windows (7/8/10). Linux (incl. distribution). macOS (El Capitan? Sierra? High Sierra?)
-->


### Repro steps
```
ng new repro-app
ng add @angular/pwa
ng build --prod --baseHref /coolapp/
```


### The log given by the failure
No failure log. 
But the ngsw.json has the following output:
```
...
"navigationUrls": [
    {
      "positive": true,
      "regex": "^\\/.*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*\\.[^/]*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*__[^/]*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*__[^/]*\\/.*$"
    }
  ]
...
```

### Desired functionality
The service worker should be scoped to the baseHref location provided in the `ng build` command. 
This way other resources on the same domain can still be loaded without beeing interfeered by the service worker. 

The desired ngsw.json would be:
```
...
"navigationUrls": [
    {
      "positive": true,
      "regex": "^\\/coolapp\\/.*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*\\.[^/]*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/de\\/ \\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*__[^/]*$"
    },
    {
      "positive": false,
      "regex": "^\\/de\\/ \\/(?:.+\\/)?[^/]*__[^/]*\\/.*$"
    }
  ]
...
```


### Mention any other details that might be useful
My Use Case:
We have an app that is shipped in multiple languages. Every language is served under a different path, e.g.:
```
https://coolapp.com/en/
https://coolapp.com/de/
```
When changing the language both service workers do collide in their responsibility, as both match their pattern: 
```
    {
      "positive": true,
      "regex": "^\\/.*$"
    }
```
and want to serve their `index.html`. By scoping them to their respective location on the server they do not collide anymore. 

### Workaround (nasty)
Define different `"ngswConfigPath": "src/ngsw-config.json"` (full duplicates) in your `angular.json` for each environment and specify the `navigationUrls` accordingly:
```
"navigationUrls": [
    "/de/**",
    "!/**/*.*",
    "! /**/*__*",
    "! /**/*__*/**"
  ]
```

Issues.Title: Useless scrollbar on main page when dialog is shown
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?

No additionnal useless scrollbar should be shown

#### What is the current behavior?

A useless disabled scrollbar is shown on main `<html>` tag, but it is not necessary

#### Explanations

It may be related to the way my page is built (I don't see this issue with the Dialog in the docs for example). When the dialog is opened, it creates a useless disabled scollbar for full page but it is never necessary.

To solve this, I just added this to my css:
```
.cdk-global-scrollblock {
  overflow-y: auto !important;
}
```
Whereas the default value is `scroll` which explains why it shows the disabled scrollbar.

If it is safe for other setups, the value should be `auto` by default. Or am I missing something?
